label: Letter from Gertrude Sanford Legendre, March 4, 1943
description: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, regarding the vacation she spent at Medway Plantation.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
8 P.M.
75		Medway-
March 4th 43-
Dear Sidney my darling,
If I could only describe the
South as graphically as you did the gunnery school-
I can first see the life of the gunnery school- I see you were
the star pupil [and] took all the honors. I do hope learning 
to shoot these guns is not going to fit you for a 
float top- please assure me there will be no chance
of that.
Now to describe to you-
first, the Palmetto Limited dropping me off with
my 3 pieces of luggage at Mt Holly at 7.45_!!
Of course no one to meet me at such an hour-
The tram has never been known to come on time
[and] certainly never ahead of schedule. The temperature
was 26[percent] [and] felt about as cold as Washington.
"Adam" was the first man I saw, he came to-
wards me down the platform in that long black over coat
[and] felt hat. We discussed the weather [and] he asked
how the [illegible] blessed your soul- soon Sam
Gantt looking more like a frilly billy cracker
than anything else in the world appeared with 
his truck- then the men gathered [and] we
started in [and] Rose met me on the road
with the Plymouth 1 2 way in, [and] soon we were
clipping down the hell to the cause way [and] the lake,
[End Page 1]
the ducks swam a little further away
[and] flapped their wings- we were under that
avenue of oaks, [and] drawing up to the brick
terrace- I stood on the terrace for a minute
[and] watched the crimson ball of sun
cast that wonderful pink [and] gold light
from behind the oak trees silluetting
them in a, blazzing glory- [illegible] lovely-
you [and] I have so often after duck 
shooting- everything is so still, the moon hangs
the mist rises, everything is covered with dew.
What peace! There is nothing like it.
The house was open- everything in place exactly 
the way you [and] I always lived in it- pictures
- curtains, books [and] ash trays- I wandered
all about [and] expected to bump into you
in every room- so queer not to find
you- I wandered to the stable, looked at
the horses with Walter- He couldn't secure
clippers so the horses look well but shaggy.
Walter runs the Plantation, is a fine fellow
I think. Dave seemed fine too-
Mrs. F [illegible] had formally secured 125 gal.
of [illegible] oil for us from the Rationing board-
Sam [illegible] the furnace with a hose with out
putting it- into the tank, because Sam insists
[End Page 2]
2
the tank leaks which accounts for our losing
that 1000 gallons- well the house was a 
ice box, so when the steam finally came on
we were able to take off our coats.
Candice, Rose, Lizzie [and] Pearl were all there.
So nice too, after all those dreadful Washington
"blacks." Rose [and] I stocked the little bar,
arranged Reggie Winn's room in the guest 
house, swept the terrace, generally worked 
most of the day. It was a cold clear
day. Isak was heart-broken over the "freeze"
killing everything [and] almost in tears he
told me his [illegible] [and] geraniums were all
frozen [and] burnt. I had Louis climb up 
a ladder to cut the vines out of my chimney
so I could light a fire in my bedroom
while every one was hard at work washing
windows, polishing floors etc. etc- a great
cloud of smoke darkened the sky- every hand
laid down what that were doing [and] went
off to the fire. It was a cross the
sea-board by Sam Gant's house- a big 
piece- considering the ground is
soaking from 2 days rain. I am surprised
[End Page 3]
this was possible- and thought the whole
thing a most typical Medway afternoon.
I wandered to the office, to your little tiny
office, to grandmothers garden- there were
a few yellow jonquils in bloom- I looked at 
Clippy's grave [and] wished he were at my
heels. Medway with out you [and] with
out dogs is a lonely, empty, eerie spot.
I expected some how to see you [and] Tanny
around a corner- it would have been 
so natural- The place really is
full of you everywhere- I can't explain
it- I went to the sheds [and] expected to
see you standing over the combine
or leaning on the tractor discussing
teh planting of lespedeza- Walter [and] Dave
both asked about you- How you were
etc.- I found it hard to talk about
you with out choking and gulping a few
unruly tears.
At five-thirty it got cold, I sat by the gun room
fire looking over our shelves of books, [and] every now
[and] again reading a portion of a poem or a diary.
[End Page 4]
3
At 7o'clock I came up to my room to
bed- Here I am- the paneled walls are lovely,
the fire is burning [and] whistling as I am
propped up wishing this to you- your bed
is so empty- what I would give to have 
you in it beside me at this moment would 
be in everything I [illegible]. I can see you
[illegible] curly head with your face burried in my
lap while I rub your curly head [and] we 
huggle [and] huggle. Medway is meant
for we two people- not for one alone. It's got
too many memories of us to gether, but I do 
feel close to you, although I feel sad-
I think these oaks, this moss, the silent, peaceful
house is just what I needed most- It 
restores one's sence of values [and] really calms
one's soul- I feel better already. A week
of this will be wonderful as I know I shall
sleep [and] sleep [and] never wake up-
I have all day to-morrow here alone
to prepare for these illustrous guests [and] Henry
Lowndes [and] Lish are coming out for supper [and] bringing the turkey
[End Page 5]
he shot for me and eight quail as well.
I found this verse to-night in a book- for you
"Though my love be further away from me
Than the east from the west or the day
from the night,
I have turned my face to his dwelling-place,
and I bid him good-night, "Goodnight,"
Oh moon shine first on my lips and then 
go shine on the forehead of him I love!
He will dream perchance that an angel's wing
Has quivered his bow above-
But thou Oh wind! lay close on his lips
The kisses thou hast in thy flight,
and he will stir in his sleep, wake
and wisper- "My heart- good night."
Good- night my heaven eyes
the wind, and the moon, and the waves
bring you all my love all the time
I shall dream we are holding each other
in our arms to-night-
Your Gertie-
[End Page 6]
